A review. New and more efficient energy conversion systems are required in the near future, due in part to the increase in oil prices and demand and also due to global warming. Fuel cells and hybrid systems present a promising future but in order to meet the demand, high amts. of hydrogen will be required. Until now, probably the cleanest method of producing hydrogen has been water electrolysis. In this field, solid oxide electrolysis cells (SOEC) have attracted a great interest in the last few years, as they offer significant power and higher efficiencies compared to conventional low temp. electrolyzers. Their applications, performances and material issues will be reviewed.

Sasaki, Kazunari; Haga, Kengo; Yoshizumi, Tomoo; Minematsu, Daisuke; Yuki, Eiji; Liu, Run Ru; Uryu, Chie; Oshima, Toshihiro; Ogura, Teppei; Shiratori, Yusuke; Ito, Kohei; Koyama, Michihisa; Yokomoto, Katsumi

Because of the fuel flexibility of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs), various types of fuels may be applied directly or via a simple reforming process, including hydrocarbons, alcs., coal gas, biogas, besides hydrogen. However, various types of minor constituents in practical fuels and/or from the system components can cause chem. degrdn. of SOFCs, such as anode and cathode poisoning phenomena. In this study, the effect is compared of various external impurities, including sulfur, chlorine, phosphorus, boron, and siloxane for anodes, and H2O and SO2 for cathodes, on SOFC performance to have a general overview on long-term chem. durability of SOFCs. Chem. compatibility of Ni with foreign species has also been thermochem. considered. Using common model cells, the stability of cell voltage, electrode overpotential, and ohmic loss up to 3000 h was exptl. examd. for H2-based fuels, for hydrocarbon-based fuels, and for partially pre-reformed CH4-based fuels. Increase in degrdn. rate by impurities was verified for various operational parameters. Impurity poisoning mechanisms are discussed for each specific impurity.

The surface chem. and the Cr tolerance ability of oxygen electrodes play a vital role in the performance and long-term stability of solid oxide cells (SOCs). In this paper, the surface cation segregations on the double-perovskite oxide PrBaCo2O5+δ (PBCO) and its relationship with Cr deposition are reported. During high-temp. annealing in an O2 atmosphere, the elements Ba and Co diffuse out of the lattice and form many BaO and Co3O4 ppts. on the surface, mainly located at grain boundaries. In the presence of volatile Cr species, the observation of BaCrO4, but not CoCr2O4, on a segregated PBCO surface reveals that the Cr deposition preferentially takes place on segregated BaO rather than on Co3O4 ppts. Our results show that segregated BaO ppts. are very active toward Cr vapor and PBCO is not a Cr-tolerant oxygen electrode for SOCs operating at high temps., despite its superior electrochem. performance.

Fast oxygen exchange kinetics, a key figure of merit in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) electrodes, is often dramatically hindered by the presence of even small concns. of impurities, for example, Si which is common in ceramics processing. In this work, rapid degrdn. of oxygen exchange kinetics was found on dense thin films of Pr0.1Ce0.9O2-δ (PCO), a mixed ionic electronic conducting electrode for SOFCs, using a new optical transmission relaxation (OTR) technique which facilitates kinetics measurements of bare film surfaces (i.e., in the absence of current collectors typical of conventional measurements). Si was identified by TEM and XPS as a significant impurity, forming a blocking layer on the electrode surface. Full recovery of oxygen exchange kinetics on the measured samples was achieved after deposition of a La oxide film. Subsequent TEM studies indicate the formation of a porous La- and Si-contg. film. Interaction between La and Si oxides was identified by a shift in the O 1s XPS peak and a systematic OTR study of films that likely react with Si (e.g., La, Sm oxides) and those that do not (e.g., Nb, Ti, Zn oxides). Preliminary measurements of OTR on a La-PCO solid soln. indicates improved long-term electrode kinetics stability, demonstrating the com. potential of this method to achieve Si impurity tolerance.

Sulfur in the air stream is one of the primary contaminants affecting the stability of cathodes in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs). In this work, sulfur poisoning of La1-xSrxCo1-yFeyO3-δ (LSCF) thin films with different compns. was investigated. The compn. of the cathode was systematically controlled by prepg. La0.75Sr0.42Co0.15Fe0.68O3-δ (A-site excess LSCF) and La0.60Sr0.39Co0.20Fe0.81O3-δ (stoichiometric LSCF) thin films on Gd-doped ceria (GDC) substrates by pulsed laser deposition. The LSCF films were then heat-treated at 800 °C for 100 h in synthetic air with a trace amt. of SO2 (ppb level). As an informative complement to the microstructural and compositional analyses, secondary ion mass spectrometry was also performed to effectively det. the extent of sulfur accumulations from LSCF cathode surface to GDC. The results showed that sulfur poisoning behavior of LSCF cathodes depends strongly on compn. The A-site excess LSCF films exhibited significant SrSO4 formation with severe porosity, whereas, only an isolated SrSO4 formation was obsd. in the stoichiometric LSCF films; instead, the partial poisoning by sulfur minimizes excessive porosity while enhancing Co-rich oxide pptn. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy was carried out to further elucidate the influence of cathode compn. on cell stability. Thermodn. considerations have been made to clarify the plausible chem. reaction mechanism between LSCF of different compns. with SO2.

Strontium-doped lanthanum cobalt ferrite (LSCF) is a widely used cathode material due to its high electronic and ionic cond., and reasonable oxygen surface exchange coeff. However, LSCF can have long-term stability issues such as surface segregation of Sr during solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) operation, which can adversely affect the electrochem. performance. Thus, understanding the nature of the Sr surface segregation phenomenon and how it is affected by the compn. of LSCF and strain are crit. In this research, heteroepitaxial thin films of La1-x SrxCo0.2Fe0.8O3-δ with varying Sr content (x = 0.4, 0.3, 0.2) were deposited by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) on single-crystal NdGaO3, SrTiO3, and GdScO3 substrates, leading to different levels of strain in the films. The extent of Sr segregation at the film surface was quantified using synchrotron-based total-reflection X-ray fluorescence (TXRF) and at. force microscopy (AFM). The electronic structure of the Sr-rich phases formed on the surface was investigated by hard XPS (HAXPES). The extent of Sr segregation was found to be a function of the Sr content in bulk. Lowering the Sr content from 40% to 30% reduced the surface segregation, but further lowering the Sr content to 20% increased the segregation. The strain of LSCF thin films on various substrates was measured using high-resoln. X-ray diffraction (HRXRD), and the Sr surface segregation was found to be reduced with compressive strain and enhanced with tensile strain present within the thin films. A model was developed correlating the Sr surface segregation with Sr content and strain effects to explain the exptl. results.

Lanthanum and/or barium strontium cobalt ferrite perovskite oxide materials are highly active cathodes for solid oxide fuel cells operated at intermediate temps. of 600-900°. However, they are vulnerable to degrdn. by chromium deposition and poisoning by volatile Cr species from chromia-forming metallic interconnects. Here we report the development of a new mixed ionic and electronic conductor, lanthanum strontium barium cobalt iron niobium oxide perovskite, (La0.24Sr0.16Ba0.6)(Co0.5Fe0.44Nb0.06)O3-δ (LSBCFN), prepd. by a novel direct mixing synthesis of (La0.6Sr0.4)(Co0.2Fe0.8)O3-δ (LSCF) and Ba(Co0.7Fe0.2Nb0.1)O3-δ (BCFN). The elec. cond. of LSBCFN is 124 S/cm at 600°, which is significantly higher than 11 S/cm measured on BCFN at the same temp. The new LSBCFN cathode which combines the structural stability and activity of BCFN and the high cond. of LSCF not only exhibits better electrochem. activity for the O2 redn. reaction than either LSCF or BCFN in the temp. range of 600-900°, but most importantly, it shows excellent stability and tolerance toward chromium deposition and poisoning under solid oxide fuel cell operation conditions. A semi-quant. anal. indicates that the Cr deposition at the electrode is closely related to the surface segregation of Sr and Ba.

Jiang, San Ping; Chen, Xinbing

A review. Intermediate-temp. solid oxide fuel cells using chromia-forming alloy interconnect requires the development of cathode not only with high electrochem. activity but also with the high resistance or tolerance towards Cr deposition and poisoning. This is due to the fact that, at solid oxide fuel cell operating temps., volatile Cr species are generated over the chromia scale, poisoning the cathodes such as (La,Sr)MnO3 and (La,Sr)(Co,Fe)O3 and causing a rapid degrdn. of the cell performance. Thus, a fundamental understanding of the interaction between the Fe-Cr alloys and solid oxide fuel cell cathode is essential for the development of high-performance and stable solid oxide fuel cells. The objective of this paper is to critically review the progress and particularly the work done in the last 10 years in this important area. The mechanism and kinetics of the Cr deposition and Cr poisoning process on the cathodes of solid oxide fuel cells are discussed. Chromium deposition at solid oxide fuel cell cathodes is most likely dominated by the chem. redn. of high valence Cr species, facilitated by the nucleation agents on the electrode and electrolyte surface and/or at the electrode/electrolyte interface, i.e., the nucleation theory. The driving force behind the nucleation theory is the surface segregation and migration of cationic species on the surface of perovskite oxide cathodes. Overwhelming evidences indicate that the surface segregation plays a crit. role in the Cr deposition. The prospect of the development of the Cr-tolerant cathodes for solid oxide fuel cells is presented.

Fe and Ni base alloys serve as materials of choice for the fabrication of stack and balance of plant components in solid oxide fuel cell power systems. The oxidn. behavior of select Fe and Ni base alloys has been investigated, and chromium evapn. rates have been exptl. measured at 850°C in 3% humidified air exposure conditions. Changes in the oxide morphol. and chem. from the alloys representing chromia former (602CA), alumina former (H214), and mixed chromia and alumina scale formers (AFA25) at 900°C and 1100°C during exposure to humidified air have been studied and are presented. It is found that the rate of Cr evapn. from the alloys decreases in the order of 602CA followed by Haynes 214 and AFA25 at 850°C during exposure to humidified air. Surface and cross-sectional scale morphologies and chem. have been examd., and variations in the Cr evapn. behavior of different alloys are discussed based on the reaction thermodn.

We have shown that the Cr deposition process at (La,Sr)MnO3 (LSM) and (La,Sr)(Co,Fe)O3 (LSCF) cathodes of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) is kinetically limited by the nucleation reaction between the gaseous Cr species and nucleation agents. In the case of the LSM electrode, the nucleation agent has been identified to be manganese species generated under cathodic polarization, and for the LSCF electrode, it is SrO species segregated at the electrode surface. Based on the mechanism proposed, we select La(Ni,Fe)O3 (LNF) and (La,Ba)(Co,Fe)O3 (LBCF) perovskites. The results show that LNF and LBCF electrodes are highly tolerant toward the Cr deposition and are much more stable than LSM and LSCF cathodes under SOFC operating conditions in the presence of a Fe-Cr metallic interconnect.

Electrochem. performance and sulfur (SO2) tolerance were studied on pristine La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3-δ (LSCF) and BaCeO3-impregnated LSCF (BaCeO3-LSCF) composite cathodes of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs). Compared to pristine LSCF electrodes, BaCeO3-LSCF composite electrodes exhibited reduced electrode polarization resistance and significantly lower activation energy for the O2 redn. reaction, indicating that BaCeO2 impregnation is effective at promoting the electrocatalytic activity of LSCF electrodes at low temps. Most significantly, BaCeO3-LSCF cathodes show remarkable tolerance and resistance towards sulfur via the formation of BaSO4 instead of SrSO4 on the electrode surface, preventing excess Sr deficiency at the A-site of LSCF perovskite and thus mitigating the sulfur poisoning effect. BaCeO3-LSCF cathodes show potential as highly active and excellent anti-sulfur oxygen electrodes for SOFCs.

Commercialization of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) is impeded by severe cathode degrdn. from the poisoning effect of contaminants commonly encountered in air (such as H2O and CO2) and from other cell components (e.g., Cr species from chromium-contg. interconnector). Here we report our findings in unraveling the mechanism of Cr poisoning of La.6Sr.4Co.2Fe.8O3 (LSCF) cathodes using our unique in situ/operando surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy. Further, we present an effective strategy to enhancing the tolerance to contaminants poisoning of LSCF cathode through infiltration of a hybrid catalyst coating, which is composed of a conformal film of perovskite PrNi.5Mn.5O3 (PNM) and exsoluted PrOx nano-particles. The coating is catalytically active to oxygen redn. reaction but inert to contaminant poisoning. When subjected to an accelerated Cr-poisoning test, the cells with a hybrid catalyst-coated LSCF cathode show excellent peak power d. (Pmax of 0.71 Wcm-2) and significantly enhanced durability (degrdn. rate of 0.0434% h-1 at 0.7 V), much better than those of cells with a bare LSCF cathode (Pmax of ∼0.46 Wcm-2 and degrdn. rate of 0.4% h-1 at 0.7 V). The results suggest that surface modification of electrodes with a coating of rationally designed catalysts is a cost-effective approach to dramatically reducing electrode degrdn. caused by contaminations.

Ferritic stainless steels have become the candidate materials for interconnects of intermediate temp. solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC). The present issues to be solved urgently for the application of ferritic stainless steel interconnects are their rapid increase in contact resistance and Cr poisoning. A chloride electrolyte suspension was developed to electro-deposit a Co-Mn alloy on a type 430 stainless steel, followed by heat treatment at 750° in Ar and at 800° in air to obtain Co-Mn spinel coatings. An adhesive and compact Co-Mn alloy layer can be deposited in the chloride soln. After heat treatment, a complex coating composed of an external MnCo2O4 layer and an inner Cr-rich oxide layer was formed on 430SS. The coating improves the oxidn. resistance of the steel at 800° in air, esp. in wet air, and inhibits the outward diffusion of Cr from the Cr-rich scale. Also, a low contact resistance was achieved with the application of the spinel coatings.

This study demonstrates the significant impact of Cr-poisoning on the performance of the LaNi0.6Fe0.4O3 (LNF) solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) cathode under current load. Volatile Cr-species, originating from a porous metallic foam, enter the working electrode and modify both the LNF cathode layer and the Gd0.4Ce0.6O1.8 (GDC) barrier layer, causing increasing overpotential and cell impedance. The increase of the ohmic resistance is caused by a decrease of the in-plane electronic cond. of the LNF layer (due to Cr incorporation and Ni removal from the LNF perovskite lattice) combined with a deterioration of the ionic cond. of the GDC barrier layer due to reactivity with Cr resulting in formation of a GdCrO3-phase. The increase of the polarization resistance is caused by a decrease of the electrochem. activity of the LNF surface towards oxygen redn. reaction at the triple phase boundary (TPB) due to Cr-incorporation in the outer shell of the LNF grains. Chem. reaction and electrochem. driven reaction of volatile Cr-species with LNF and GDC contributes to the extrinsic degrdn. of the LNF cathodes under current load.

A review. With the redn. of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) operating temp. to the range of 600 °C-800 °C, metallic alloy with high oxidn. resistance are used to replace traditional ceramic interconnects. Metallic interconnects is advantageous over ceramic interconnects; in terms of manufacturability, cost, mech. strength, and elec. cond. To date, promising candidates for metallic interconnects are all Cr-contg. alloys, which are susceptible to volatile Cr migration that causes cell degrdn. As such, protective coatings have been developed to effectively inhibit Cr migration; as well as maintain excellent elec. cond. and good oxidn. resistance. This article reviews the progress and tech. challenges in developing metallic interconnects; different types of protective coatings and deposition techniques for metallic interconnects for intermediate-temp. SOFC applications.

Stability of SrO-NiO solid soln. synthesized from low cost alk. earth and transition metal nitrate salts is studied for application as a gaseous chromium getter in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC). Phase identification and its evolution has been examd. using high temp. in-situ X-ray diffraction (HT-XRD) whereas thermal stability and morphol. of compds. have been studied using XRD in combination with SEM (SEM). Synthesized SrxNiyOz powder remains stable up to 900°C in air, whereas exposure above 950°C leads to its dissocn. into sep. SrO and NiO phases. Presence of SrO in powder reacts with H2O and CO2, present in atm. air, resulting into pulverization due to vol. change and the formation of hydroxides and carbonates. Thermogravimetric anal. (TGA) of the pulverized powders show approx. 20% wt. loss due to the evapn. of hydroxyl and carbonate groups. Chem. stability of SrxNiyOz is considered essential in order to prevent pulverization and flaking of the getter coating applied over ceramic honeycomb or foam substrates. Chromium getter is considered a cost effective and reliable means to mitigate cathode poisoning in high temp. electrochem. systems such as solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cell (SOEC) and oxygen transport membranes (OTM).

Cr getters composed of Sr Ni oxide (Sr9Ni7O21) offer a cost-effective pathway for the mitigation of cathode poisoning in solid oxide fuel cells by capturing gaseous Cr species. The getter material, however, remains prone to chem. and structural changes in humid environments. Exptl. observations indicate that Sr is segregated by absorbing H2O mols. and the resulting Sr-deficient phase is transformed into SrNiO3. Studies reveal that the Sr-segregation is attributed not only to the hygroscopic nature of Sr but also to the compressive stress and 1-dimensional arrangement of Sr-ions in the structure. The formation of Sr(OH)2.8H2O by moisture absorption accompanies vol. expansion, resulting in crack formation. To improve the resistance to moisture attack, the surface is modified with SrCO3 layer by CO2-treatment. Exptl. observations confirm that the SrCO3 passivation layer effectively restrains the moisture absorption and accompanied structural changes. The Cr-gettering capability of the SrCO3 layer on Sr Ni oxide is exptl. and thermodynamically verified.

Chromium (Cr) poisoning is one of the major causes of cathode degrdn. in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC). In this study, a computational model of Cr getter is discussed to optimize the design of getter for efficient capture of Cr and higher utilization. Monolithic substrate with 400 cpsi (cells per square inch) has been considered as the initial getter support structure with a coating thickness of 10 μm and 50% porosity. Design parameters include operating conditions of 1 kW SOFC system. Numerical results show that the getter design and configurations can be developed and optimized for systems life ranging from 40,000 to 50,000 h. Initial exptl. and modeling results are presented. Approaches for improving getter utilization and life are discussed.

The effect of sulfur deposition and poisoning on the electrochem. activity of La0.8Sr0.2MnO3 (LSM) cathode of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) for the O2 redn. reaction is investigated. Sulfur poisoning of the electrochem. activity of LSM electrodes is characterized by two-stage degrdn. processes: initial rapid degrdn. by the adsorbed SO2 on the surface of LSM electrodes, inhibiting the dissocn. adsorption and diffusion processes of oxygen, followed by a slow degrdn. due to the deposition and formation of SrSO4 on the LSM electrode surface and at the three phase boundaries. The degrdn. due to the adsorption of SO2 is largely reversible and characterized by the initial rapid increase of polarization potential, ΔE. The ΔE for the O2 redn. reaction at 800°C is significantly smaller than that for the reaction at 700°C in the presence of 1 ppm and 10 ppm SO2 in air due to the reduced adsorption of SO2 on LSM electrode surface. However, the sulfur deposition and poisoning on the LSM cathodes is not reversible as the result of the formation of SrSO4, which in turn accelerates the Sr segregation and consequently depletes Sr content at the A-site of LSM, leading to the significant degrdn. of the electrochem. activity of LSM electrodes. The sulfur deposition process is most likely controlled by the nucleation reaction between gaseous SO2 and segregated SrO, forming SrSO4.

In this work we investigate the effect of Cr-poisoning at OCV-condition by means of electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The anode-supported cell (ASC) is operated in Cr-free environment for the first 70 h of the cell test at 800 °C supplying air to the cathode and a varying mixt. of H2O/H2 to the anode. The performance of the cell is detd. by current-voltage (CV) measurement after the start up. After an operating time of 70 h in the absence of chromium species a Cr-source was switched on by passing the oxidant (air) through a Crofer22APU powder bed. In order to det. the degrdn. caused by Cr-poisoning elec. impedance spectra are collected at every 29 h of operating time. After further 275 h at OCV-condition in the presence of Cr-source another CV-curve is measured. A detailed anal. of the measured impedance spectra by the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) enables a sepn. of the cathode polarization resistance. During the Cr-free operation the cathode polarization shows a const. value. After the Cr-source is switched on a strong increase of the cathode polarization resistance is obsd. This unique result shows clearly that Cr-poisoning of an LSM/8YSZ-cathode already takes place at OCV-condition.

Sulfur in the air stream is one of the major contaminants affecting the performance stability of cathodes of solid oxide fuel cells(SOFCs) such as La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3-δ (LSCF) and La0.8Sr0.2MnO3 (LSM) perovskite oxide. In this paper, the effects of operating temps. and SO2 concns. on the electrochem. performance of LSCF and LSM cathodes are investigated. Sulfur poisoning effect is more pronounced at lower temps. for LSM and LSCF cathodes, i.e., 700° C. Sulfur deposition occurs inside the LSCF electrodes according to TOF-SIMS results and is most pronounced on the surface of LSCF at 700° C, forming primarily SrSO4. For LSM, sulfur deposition is more obvious on the interface of LSM/YSZ at 800° C by Nano-SIMS results. The reaction mechanism between sulfur dioxide and LSCF and LSM electrodes is then discussed.

It was shown through a comprehensive impedance spectroscopy study that the impedance of the classic composite LSM:YSZ (La Sr manganite and yttria stabilized zirconia) solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) cathode can be described well with porous electrode theory. Also, it was illustrated through a literature review on SOFC electrodes that porous electrode theory not only describes the classic LSM:YSZ SOFC cathode well, but SOFC electrodes in general. The extensive impedance spectroscopy study of LSM:YSZ cathodes consisted of measurements on cathodes with three different sintering temps. and hence different microstructures and varying degrees of LSM/YSZ solid state interactions. LSM based composite cathodes, where YSZ was replaced with CGO was also studied to acquire further knowledge on the chem. compatibility between LSM and YSZ. All impedance measurements were acquired in the very broad temp. range of 200-900° for complete elucidation of the impedance. All impedance spectra were analyzed in terms of porous electrode theory. Phys. materials parameters were extd. from the anal., which were in excellent accordance with literature values. Valuable insight about the dissoln. of Mn in the cathode composite material YSZ during prepn. was also provided along with valuable engineering characteristics such as the electrochem. use thickness. From the combined impedance study and literature review, it is clear, that porous electrode theory is the most suitable framework for any type of porous composite SOFC electrode evaluation.

Sr-doped lanthanum manganite (LSM) is a widely used cathode material in solid oxide fuel cells. Despite being a poor ion conductor, LSM electrodes can reduce oxygen via two pathways: a three-phase boundary surface path which includes surface diffusion of oxygen species and oxide ion incorporation at the three-phase boundary, and a bulk path based on oxygen diffusion in LSM. In this work, the kinetics of both paths and their dependence on temp. and electrode geometry is investigated by impedance spectroscopy on micropatterned LSM thin-film electrodes. Differently shaped and sized macroscopic and microscopic LSM electrodes as well as LSM electrodes with oxygen blocking Pt capping layers are employed to identify two parallel reaction pathways of oxygen redn. On circular microelectrodes the three-phase boundary surface path carries most of the current in the lower temp. region (.ltorsim.700°), while at high temps. (⪆700°) the bulk path is dominating. The significance of each redn. path also depends on the microstructure of the columnar LSM films which can be changed by varying pulsed laser deposition parameters or by annealing. Moreover, relevance of a pseudo-three-phase boundary path across edges of the LSM electrodes is discussed.

A review. A major degrdn. mechanism in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) is poisoning of the cathode by chromium from volatilization of the interconnect material. The chromium deposition has been attributed to both chem. and electrochem. mechanisms. For an electrochem. reaction, deposition can occur only where both ions and electrons are available, which, for a purely ionic conducting electrolyte and a purely electronic conducting cathode, can occur only at the three-phase gas-electrolyte-electrode interface. However, the introduction of ionic cond. into the cathode or electronic cond. into the electrolyte can allow deposition to occur away from this three-phase interface, and thus alter its effect on the fuel cell performance. In this paper, the chromium poisoning of SOFC cathodes is reviewed, with a focus on the effects of the transport properties of the cathode and electrolyte materials.

Oxygen redn. at the mixed ionic and electronic conductive (MIEC) SOFC cathodes occur along a surface pathway with oxygen transport through a triple-phase boundary (3PB), and/or a bulk pathway via bulk cathode and electrolyte/cathode interface (2PB). The identification of the rate-limiting steps (RLSs) for each path and understand on their interactions are important to the SOFC cathode kinetics. In this research a modified one-dimensional continuum model is developed to analyze the oxygen redn. on LSM-type MIEC cathode by incorporating multi-step charge-transfer into the bi-pathway kinetics. Finite control-vol. method is used to simulate the pathway kinetic competition, and a parametric study is performed with different equil. concns. of surface oxygen ion and bulk oxygen vacancy. The I-V profiles show kinetic transition from 3PB-control to 2PB-control at overpotentials from -0.2 V to -0.4 V, and the active reaction zone in concn. profiles expands from 3PB/2PB interfaces by 2-4 μm. The exchange and local 3PB currents recognized from simulation indicate limit of surface oxygen diffusion as the mechanistic process for pathway transition. The results are compared to the reported exptl. findings to examine the model's assumption of oxygen redn. scenario, and its potential implication on SOFC cathode performance improvement.

Among the phenomena related to the surface rearrangement of cations in perovskite-based oxides, A-site cation enrichment, Sr in particular, near the surface has been frequently obsd. Upon annealing in an oxidizing atm., Sr is often enriched on the surface as compared with the bulk compn. of the material, which eventually forms Sr-rich phases or rearranges the crystal structure of the surface. This Sr segregation changes the structure and compn. of the perovskite surfaces and thus affects the stability of the materials and the reactivity with gas phases. In this regard, many studies have been carried out in the field of solid oxide electrochem. cells (SOCs). In this review, we summarize the latest research efforts on Sr segregation in perovskite-based SOC O2 electrodes, with a focus on how excess Sr is present. We then discuss the origins of Sr segregation and suggest strategies for suppressing it to realize high-performance perovskite-based O2 electrodes.

Cation segregation on perovskite oxide surfaces affects vastly the oxygen redn. activity and stability of solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) cathodes. A unified theory that explains the phys. origins of this phenomenon is therefore needed for designing cathode materials with optimal surface chem. We quant. assessed the elastic and electrostatic interactions of the dopant with the surrounding lattice as the key driving forces for segregation on model perovskite compds., LnMnO3 (host cation Ln = La, Sm). Our approach combines surface chem. anal. with X-ray photoelectron and Auger electron spectroscopy on model dense thin films and computational anal. with d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. and anal. models. Elastic energy differences were systematically induced in the system by varying the radius of the selected dopants (Ca, Sr, Ba) with respect to the host cations (La, Sm) while retaining the same charge state. Electrostatic energy differences were introduced by varying the distribution of charged oxygen and cation vacancies in our models. Varying the oxygen chem. potential in our expts. induced changes in both the elastic energy and electrostatic interactions. Our results quant. demonstrate that the mechanism of dopant segregation on perovskite oxides includes both the elastic and electrostatic energy contributions. A smaller size mismatch between the host and dopant cations and a chem. expanded lattice were found to reduce the segregation level of the dopant and to enable more stable cathode surfaces. Ca-doped LaMnO3 was found to have the most stable surface compn. with the least cation segregation among the compns. surveyed. The diffusion kinetics of the larger dopants, Ba and Sr, was found to be slower and can kinetically trap the segregation at reduced temps. despite the larger elastic energy driving force. Lastly, scanning probe image contrast showed that the surface chem. heterogeneities made of dopant oxides upon segregation were electronically insulating. The consistency between the results obtained from expts., DFT calcns., and anal. theory in this work provides a predictive capability to tailor the cathode surface compns. for high-performance SOFCs.

Although perovskite oxides hold promise in applications ranging from solid oxide fuel cells to catalysts, their surface chem. is poorly understood at the mol. level. The formation of the first monolayer of water at the (001) surfaces of Srn+1RunO3n+1 (n = 1, 2) has been studied using low-temp. scanning tunnelling microscopy, XPS, and d. functional theory. These layered perovskites cleave between neighboring SrO planes, yielding almost ideal, rocksalt-like surfaces. An adsorbed monomer dissocs. and forms a pair of hydroxide ions. The OH stemming from the original mol. stays trapped at Sr-Sr bridge positions, circling the surface OH with a measured activation energy of 187 ± 10 meV. At higher coverage, dimers of dissocd. water assemble into one-dimensional chains and form a percolating network where water adsorbs molecularly in the gaps. Our work shows the limitations of applying surface chem. concepts derived for binary rocksalt oxides to perovskites.

SrMnO3 is a perovskite compd. which, unlike most perovskites, can be synthesized in three different but closely related polymorphs. In this paper, an exptl. equation of state of the 6H polymorph is reported. The exptl. detd. bulk modulus of SrMnO3 increases from 115.6(11) GPa in the 4H polymorph to 143.7(17) GPa in the 6H polymorph, while d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. predict a further increase to 172.5(4) GPa in the 3C polymorph. In situ observations of transformations between the three known polymorphs, under high pressure and high temp. conditions, are also reported. The results are compared with extensive DFT calcns. and literature, and it is demonstrated that the 6H polymorph is the thermodynamically stable phase between 5.9(3) and 18.1(2) GPa at 0 K. The effect of possible oxygen substoichiometry is also explored, using DFT. Finally, the findings are combined with the existing knowledge of the phase behavior in this system to outline where further knowledge needs to be collected before a pressure/temp. (PT) phase diagram can be constructed for this system.

A thermodn. assessment of the Sr-Mn-O system is presented. The main practical relevance of this system is that it contains the perovskite phase SrMnO3, which is the Sr-rich end member of the phase (La,Sr)MnO3, that finds widespread use as a cathode material for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) and has recently attracted a lot of attention due to its interesting giant magnetoresistive properties. The thermodn. parameters are optimized by applying the CALPHAD method. The SrMnO3-z phase exists in two modifications, a layered hexagonal modification at low temps. and a perovskite modification at high temps. Both modifications show considerable oxygen deficiencies, which are modeled using the compd. energy model. The sublattice occupation of the phases is (Sr2+) (Mn3+, Mn4+)(O2-, Va)3. On reducing Mn4+ to Mn3+, oxygen vacancies are formed. The phase SrMn3O6-z also shows an oxygen deficiency, which is modeled in an identical way. The Ruddlesden-Popper phases Sr2MnO4 and Sr3Mn2O7, and the phases Sr7Mn4O15 and Sr4Mn3O10 are modeled as stoichiometric phases. The ionic liq. is modeled using the two-sublattice model for ionic liqs. The stability and thermodn. data on many of the phases in this system are poorly known. For this reason, some aspects of this assessment must be regarded as tentative.

The Mn-O system contains the phases manganosite (Mn1-xO), α-hausmannite (α-Mn3O4, transforms to β-Mn3O4 at >1450 K), β-bixbyite (β-Mn2O3, transforms to α-Mn2O3 at <300 K), and pyrolusite (MnO2). Apart from these phases, quite a no. of metastable modifications exists; they are out of the present consideration. Reaction of manganese and some of the enumerated oxides with oxygen is included in the consideration. Exptl. data on the thermodn. and the phase diagram of the Mn-O system were reviewed, and by application of the CALPHAD method, a consistent set of thermodn. model parameters was optimized. The phases pyrolusite (MnO2), bixbyite (Mn2O3), and hausmannite (Mn3O4) were described as stoichiometric compds. Manganosite (Mn1-xO) was described using the compd.-energy model and the liq. described using the two-sublattice model for ionic liqs.

Several spinel samples, i.e., MnxCr3-xO4 (0.5 ≤ x ≤ 2.5), NiCr2O4 and CoCr2O4, were synthesized and studied in terms of phase anal., d., elec. resistivity and thermal expansion behavior. The spinel samples were generally single phase; exceptions included MnCr2O4 and Mn0.5Cr2.5O4 with significant amts. of Cr2O3 and NiCr2O4 with trace amts. of NiO. Porosity, in general, decreased with increasing sintering temp., except for Mn0.5Cr2.5O4, which showed increasing porosity with increasing sintering temp. NiCr2O4, CoCr2O4 and MnCr2O4, all had similar thermal expansion behavior, with thermal expansion coeffs. (TEC) ranging from 7.2-7.6 × 10-6/°C. The TEC difference between the spinels and ferritic stainless steel was larger than the difference between the steel and chromia, which had a TEC of 9.6 × 10-6/°C. The spinels and chromia exhibited semiconductor-type behavior, with elec. resistivities decreasing with increasing temp. Only Mn2CrO4 and NiCr2O4 had resistivities lower than Cr2O3 over the entire temp. range of testing (20-900 °C). For MnxCr3-xO4, resistivity decreased with increasing Mn content.

We report on the 1st optical characterization of both cubic and hexagonal SrMnO3. Room-temp. Raman spectra collected by a micro-Raman spectrometer are shown. The spectrum of the cubic compd. is characterized by weak and broad bands in agreement with group theory which predicts no Raman-active phonons for this compd. On the other hand, the spectrum of the hexagonal compd. shows 6 narrow peaks ascribed to 1-phonon processes. A complete polarization anal. of the spectra collected from a single crystallite allows us to completely assign the symmetries of the 6 obsd. peaks. At. displacements for all phonon peaks are also proposed.

Heterogeneous catalysts, which allow a reductive activation of dioxygen (O2) under mild reaction conditions, are promising candidates for highly efficient aerobic oxidn. An effective hexagonal SrMnO3 (SMO) perovskite catalyst for liq.-phase selective oxidn. with O2 was successfully synthesized by the polymd. complex method. The activity of SMO for the aerobic oxidn. of alcs. was higher than those of typical manganese oxide-based catalysts and was heterogeneous, so that the recovered catalyst could be reused without heat treatment under oxidative conditions while keeping its high catalytic performance. The reversible reaction on the surface Mn species on SMO with O2 leads to the formation of Mn-superoxo species, which catalyze the selective oxidative transformation of various types of org. substrates into the desired oxygenated or dehydrogenated products.

Computational design anal. of a high performance cathode is a cost-effective means of exploring new microstructure and material options for solid oxide fuel cells. A two-layered porous cathode design has been developed that includes a thinner layer with smaller grain diams. at the cathode/electrolyte interface followed by a relatively thicker outer layer with larger grains at the electrode/oxidant interface. Results are presented for the detn. of spatially dependent current generation distributions, assessment of the importance of concn. polarization, and sensitivity to measurable microstructural variables. Ests. of the electrode performance in air at 700 °C indicate that performance approaching 3.1 A/cm2 at 0.078 V is theor. possible. The limitations of the model are described, along with efforts needed to verify and refine the predictions. The feasibility of fabricating the electrode configuration is also discussed.

Thermodn. data for the computation of the vaporization of Cr2O3(s) in humid air show significant deviations between each other, which leads to large differences in the computed partial pressures. The vaporization of Cr2O3(s) in air with different humidities, p(H2O) = 0.0007 to 0.3 bar, was investigated at a const. temp. of 1223 K by the vapor transpiration method. The results obtained are explained by the formation of CrO3(g) as the major vapor species at low p(H2O) and the formation of CrO2(OH)2(g) as the major vapor species at high p(H2O). The pressures evaluated are compared with those obtained by thermodn. computations using different databases.
